title: Robot Navigation Algorithm Design and Language-Based Environmental Description Practice

context.prior_knowledge: Intermediate-level specialized knowledge and problem-solving skills, technical report writing, and foundational comprehension of basic scientific texts
context.additional_context: Projects centered on interpreting ultrasound sensor data using smartphone-based simulation tools. Language-based activities such as organizing technical terminology, documenting experimental results, and creating presentation materials are emphasized.

learning_goals: Students construct 2D maps of indoor environments using grid-based map generation algorithms and describe spatial information in linguistic text.
Students design environmental information integration strategies to compensate for ultrasonic sensor limitations and document them in technical report format.

Students complete a six-step process (Problem Definition → Algorithm Design → Simulation → Implementation → Testing → Report Writing) to solve real robot navigation problems (e.g., maze exploration, obstacle avoidance) in 3–4-member team projects over six months. They achieve ≥70 points in final presentations based on evaluation criteria (Functionality 40%, Creativity 30%, Collaboration 30%) and synthesize project results through technical and linguistic expression.
Learners can develop algorithms to optimize obstacle-avoidance paths by applying Behavior Learning techniques and analyze experimental results in a structured text format.

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
